alert.note: Alert for Alger; Baraga; Delta; Dickinson; Gogebic; Houghton; Iron; Keweenaw; Luce; Marquette; Menominee; Northern Schoolcraft; Ontonagon; Southern Houghton; Southern Schoolcraft (Michigan) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued March 29 at 5:04PM EDT by NWS Marquette
info.description: ...Two rounds of potentially significant wintry precipitation Thursday night through early Saturday... As warmer air and moisture surge north toward Upper Michigan Thursday night, snow will rapidly spread from southwest to northeast across Upper Michigan, likely beginning around sunset near the Michigan Wisconsin stateline. Once the snow begins, it may fall heavily for a few hours, leading to several inches of wet, dense snow accumulation. As warmer air streams into the area, the snow may then change to freezing rain, especially across the southern half of Upper Michigan. A glaze of ice accumulation will be possible. The freezing rain may change to rain late across southern Upper Michigan. All of the precipitation will then diminish late Thursday night and Friday morning. For a good portion of the day on Friday, areas of mainly just light rain and drizzle will occur as temperatures rise to at least a little above freezing. A second wave of heavy precipitation will then develop late Friday afternoon and evening as low pressure tracks northeast to Lower Michigan. This heavy precipitation will begin as rain or a wintry mix that will change to snow during Friday night. Significant accumulations of wet, dense snow will be possible. The lowest snow accumulations with this second round of snowfall will be across northwest Upper Michigan. With strong northeast winds gusting to 30 to 40 mph accompanying the snow Friday night, the accumulation of wet snow on trees and powerlines could result in some tree damage and power outages. Snow will quickly diminish and end Saturday morning, but winds will be a little slower to diminish. Be sure to monitor the latest forecasts for updates on these two rounds of potentially significant wintry precipitation, and consider changing travel plans.
